see the world--if you wish 10 know what crudtles
and qualities exist in the human race, go to the
printing Office, when the paper is published. and

Of Jackson and the brave,
The day 10 mem'ry bring,
When TO battle DER the wave,
Came tile host of EngIand's king
And their ships poured them out along the stran
Our hearts OF sterling gold,
Saw their phaanxcs unfold,
And Packenham the bold
Led the band
In colnmn close they form,
AS the signal rocket flew,
And OH our lines to storm,
lii the deepest silence drew
Il was on winter lDorn, as they teH
When threat'nng came the crowd,
Like a red Sirucco cloud,
Which would wrap US in It's shrond
As il fell
The blood within us rushed
To meet at once the foe,
But The throbDng heart was hushed,
To strike dea,llier nlow:
Fire at length, our Captains cried, when huzza
Broke ont upon their slgnt,
sheet Of yullied light
As volcano was It bright
On the air.
Iuzza huzza huzza
Destruction ragged around,
And our thunderholts Of war,
Scat er'd havnc oer the ground
And The pride of British hearts gan TO quail,
In anguish now they wheel,
And in path of blood they reel,
Yet those are hearts Of steel
Though they fail
The carnage it is done,
Their thousands strew the plain,
What courage could, they won,
They squt themselves like men,
And the laurel Of the brave never dies
Rnt let Old England hear US,
If agaa she come so near us
'rwere better far to fear US
Than de.pse.-
But ere the song be ended,
The tribute let us pay,
To him whose skill defended
Ou. commonwealth tha, day;
A watchword be his name to the free.
No dangers shall appal,
Let US gather at the call,
To conquer or to fall


As would lie 80


Then loud the song be sounded,
The storm be ever blest,
Which Br,ans force confounded
The storm from out the West;
And Jackson be the theme of every tongue,
Our sons shall read the story,
of battle field SO CORY,


High in the niche of glory
twill be hung


And when summon'd to his rest,
To his place in yonder skies,
Then strike the manly breast,
BE the tear in woDan's eyes;
Ifhomc to her bosom yet be dear,
Let her sit in sadness pale,
And her sigh be on the gale,


As in anguish she snail wall,
by hrs bier

Mr.. Vinegar Cruet the village grocer, wished
that " Smoked Herrings' might be put in Capt.

A young gentleman entered and handed small
packet OF papers the editor, and left the Office.
His manner plainly enough indicated that he be-
onged to the class OF idlers who contributed their
mites to the ephemeral columns OF the day.


:" Mr.. Editor'' said lat old fellow, who sat
wheeling in his easy chair, you give too much
room to such idle fellows who cares for their liter
ature and their essays had rather read debate
Of Congress, Legislature, than all the litera-
~ trash which the whole tribe OF seribblers can
furnish in year.


"Perhaps. MIR. Grumblegumpon, it may be so
with you but you will be good to recollect that
there are numerous persons who patroDze paper
merely for the misc celaneous articles il contains,
and who rarely if ever oi k at congressional de-
bate; and we caterers for the public must consult


the inclination and taste OF ALL so far az is consistent

tion, " that no advantage whateyeris derived from
all the tales. essays, and poetry which the present
generation has produced; they only
:" MIR. Editor" said young lady. who had that
moment entered, will you please to hand me your
last paper, containing the prize essay Of the Dream
Of Love- from the New York Mirror
| II was given her, and with smile, and look.
which would not have exchanged for all the cor
gressional debates in the universe, with old Grum
bell to boot she retired.


"There," continued he, "such the persons
for whom you exclude the wisdom OF sages and
researches of our Legislative has.'

inquired for paper; handed him, and
turning i. over, said his object in calling was TO ex

II was easy 10 perceive the OF Office felt his

and supdry,' he was moving towards the door, with
an evident intention Of taking himself off
! "Wait if you please, one momen." said the Ed
! itor, merely wish to whisper in your ear that
before proceeding in this affair, it may be well to

4 in the political world he surveys the mass OF kna
very and loly with which i, abounds he embodes

i Pale with rage, Smellfungus closed the door with

state so far as they are connected with Bank trans
actions The case was that Of the Bank OF Utica Us.
Philip Wager, which is thus stated !" his action
brough, the court below Tor the recovery OF the
amount OF note discounted at the Bank OF Utica,
which was resisted by the defendants, the gound
OF nsury, because that, in discounng the note the
bank agents retained the interest in advance charged
interest for the three days grace and also because
the bank agents, in computing the interest, caicu
lated il al 80 days for each month, by which mode
but three hundred and sixty days allowed to
the year." The decision Of '.the Court below
was, that the note roid on account of usury.
The Judgment Of the Court below was affirmed
in the Court Of Errors, by Is to 8. This de-
cision appears to US to be clearly against equity,
however it may comport with law. The prac-
tice, here so severely denounced as to yiate con-
tracts connected with it, is universal, 10 Bank trans
sctions. An attempt was made, by Mr.. GOLDEN,
who was one Of the Judges in this to obtain
whist he was Member Of the House oil Represent.
atives of the United States, decision Of the House,
on the grounds against the legality OF dis
counts by the Bank Of the United States and its
Branches But, it failed, The usage being too well
established 10 be shaken on light grounds For
selves owe more money to Banks than We chlsc
to take any pride in telling but we trust the evil OF
this decision will be limited TO the State OF New
York. where enough Of evil will be worked, by lis
favoring those who may avail themselves oil IT. TO





Ito the defeat of The ends Of jusce--and to the
prostration of public morals.


Thus one explosion alter another reaches us
from the combustible region ofthe great State. The
quet citizen Of hat State, who is spectator mere
ny, mus, feel himself, after one OF these shocks, 10
be somewhat in the condition Of the honest tar, who
was blown .sky high" at iuggler's exhibition, and,
on re-landing on mother earth with whole bones,
tonshed at his involuntary somerset, wondered
" hat the d-l they would do lcxt.1 ". lntet.


We are glad to hear that the suit, recently deci-
Eded by the Court of Errors Of the State Of New
York nullifyine all bank discounts made upon usual
principles has been so long pending that The Banks
have had warning enough TO change their usage. so
that, comparatively, little evil will flow from this
decision, however dangerous the principle OF it.


Nat. Intet.
| Baltimore, January 2--it is an unfortunate cir
cumsance for the Indians in the yincinity OF Geor-
gia that any thing should occur TO render them OBJ
noxious 10 their neighbours, as ftom the well known
dispositions Of the Georgians esinced on many occa-
slons there is little hope for those tribes who unwil
tngy provoke the resentment o the frontier settlers
backed by the power OF the stae. The Florida In
dams having recensiy committed murders and culra-
geo u"utfending citizens OF Georgia, SO say the
accounts, severe retaliation will in all probability,
be the consequence; and from the following resclu.
tons passed by the Legislature 0! Georgia, it is esi
dent that the indiscrcon OF the Indians will be
promptly punished We give it the mild term Of
indscretion because the conduct ofhe Indians is so
frequently misrepresened and exaggerated, and SO
frequently the resut OF bad advice received from the
whites, who urge them TO commit Offences hat they
may be driven further into the wilderness and their
possessions forfeited TO the cunning of their destroy
ers We seldom hear any thing Of the exciting
causes which urge The Indian TO war parte
statement, put forth by the successful TO suit their
oxun nd the NJ he
Indian, sufIces, and we look on with apathy at the
anhihilstion Of whole tribe driven TO desperation
by the ingenuity OF their oppressofs. Gazette.


RESOLUTIONS


PASSED BY THE LEGISLATURE OF GEORGIA.


Whereas his Exceency the Governor has re-
celsed and communicated TO this Legislature, in
formation that recent murders have been perpera-
ted upon certain citizens o this State on The Florida
line, by the Seminole Lower Creek Indians and
that murders have been repeated near the same
place upon individuals living on the Florida side Of
said line And further, that the Indians painted and
prepared for hostilies on the frontiers OF the State
having been taken by the United States force situa-
ted in that quarter, from whom information is re-
eeived that two hundred Indians embodied and
ready to make an invasion upon the settlers OF this
State and the danger oil such an invasion being SO ii
minent as to admit OF no delsy-


Resolved, That his Excellency the Governor take
immediate steps, by the Of the Militia or youn-
teer companies Of this State. TO lepe said invasion
as he may think proper either by arms or iortihca-
tions and in sufficient force to afford protection to
our frontiers and tha. the expense Of said expedi
ton be betrayed ou, Of the fund appropriated ior Mil
itary purposes.


/ Resolved, That, as il is provided by the 9th
ton of the first article Of the Federal Constitution
the General Government is bonnd to suppress in
surrec,ions and to repel invasons; and also o the
4th section of the 4th article Of said Constitution, Is
pledged to protect each state against invason--lhas
the Governor, without delay. call upon the Govern

RATTLE OF NEW ORLEANS.
full articles.article:
Of Jackson and the brave,
The day 10 mem'ry bring,
When TO battle DER the wave,
Came tile host of EngIand's king
And their ships poured them out along the stran
Our hearts OF sterling gold,
Saw their phaanxcs unfold,
And Packenham the bold
Led the band
In colnmn close they form,
AS the signal rocket flew,
And OH our lines to storm,
lii the deepest silence drew
Il was on winter lDorn, as they teH
When threat'nng came the crowd,
Like a red Sirucco cloud,
Which would wrap US in It's shrond
As il fell
The blood within us rushed
To meet at once the foe,
But The throbDng heart was hushed,
To strike dea,llier nlow:
Fire at length, our Captains cried, when huzza
Broke ont upon their slgnt,
sheet Of yullied light
As volcano was It bright
On the air.
Iuzza huzza huzza
Destruction ragged around,
And our thunderholts Of war,
Scat er'd havnc oer the ground
And The pride of British hearts gan TO quail,
In anguish now they wheel,
And in path of blood they reel,
Yet those are hearts Of steel
Though they fail
The carnage it is done,
Their thousands strew the plain,
What courage could, they won,
They squt themselves like men,
And the laurel Of the brave never dies
Rnt let Old England hear US,
If agaa she come so near us
'rwere better far to fear US
Than de.pse.-
But ere the song be ended,
The tribute let us pay,
To him whose skill defended
Ou. commonwealth tha, day;
A watchword be his name to the free.
No dangers shall appal,
Let US gather at the call,
To conquer or to fall


As would lie 80


Then loud the song be sounded,
The storm be ever blest,
Which Br,ans force confounded
The storm from out the West;
And Jackson be the theme of every tongue,
Our sons shall read the story,
of battle field SO CORY,


High in the niche of glory
twill be hung


And when summon'd to his rest,
To his place in yonder skies,
Then strike the manly breast,
BE the tear in woDan's eyes;
Ifhomc to her bosom yet be dear,
Let her sit in sadness pale,
And her sigh be on the gale,


As in anguish she snail wall,

A young gentleman entered and handed small

His manner plainly enough indicated that he be-
onged to the class OF idlers who contributed their
mites to the ephemeral columns OF the day.


:" Mr.. Editor'' said lat old fellow, who sat

room to such idle fellows who cares for their liter

Of Congress, Legislature, than all the litera-

and supdry,' he was moving towards the door, with

before proceeding in this affair, it may be well to

state so far as they are connected with Bank trans
actions The case was that Of the Bank OF Utica Us.
Philip Wager, which is thus stated !" his action
brough, the court below Tor the recovery OF the
amount OF note discounted at the Bank OF Utica,
which was resisted by the defendants, the gound
OF nsury, because that, in discounng the note the
bank agents retained the interest in advance charged
interest for the three days grace and also because
the bank agents, in computing the interest, caicu
lated il al 80 days for each month, by which mode
but three hundred and sixty days allowed to
the year." The decision Of '.the Court below
was, that the note roid on account of usury.
The Judgment Of the Court below was affirmed
in the Court Of Errors, by Is to 8. This de-
cision appears to US to be clearly against equity,
however it may comport with law. The prac-
tice, here so severely denounced as to yiate con-
tracts connected with it, is universal, 10 Bank trans
sctions. An attempt was made, by Mr.. GOLDEN,
who was one Of the Judges in this to obtain
whist he was Member Of the House oil Represent.
atives of the United States, decision Of the House,
on the grounds against the legality OF dis
counts by the Bank Of the United States and its
Branches But, it failed, The usage being too well
established 10 be shaken on light grounds For
selves owe more money to Banks than We chlsc
to take any pride in telling but we trust the evil OF
this decision will be limited TO the State OF New
York. where enough Of evil will be worked, by lis
favoring those who may avail themselves oil IT. TO





Ito the defeat of The ends Of jusce--and to the
prostration of public morals.


Thus one explosion alter another reaches us
from the combustible region ofthe great State. The
quet citizen Of hat State, who is spectator mere
ny, mus, feel himself, after one OF these shocks, 10
be somewhat in the condition Of the honest tar, who
was blown .sky high" at iuggler's exhibition, and,
on re-landing on mother earth with whole bones,
tonshed at his involuntary somerset, wondered
" hat the d-l they would do lcxt.1 ". lntet.


We are glad to hear that the suit, recently deci-
Eded by the Court of Errors Of the State Of New
York nullifyine all bank discounts made upon usual
principles has been so long pending that The Banks
have had warning enough TO change their usage. so
that, comparatively, little evil will flow from this
decision, however dangerous the principle OF it.

| Baltimore, January 2--it is an unfortunate cir
cumsance for the Indians in the yincinity OF Geor-
gia that any thing should occur TO render them OBJ
noxious 10 their neighbours, as ftom the well known
dispositions Of the Georgians esinced on many occa-
slons there is little hope for those tribes who unwil
tngy provoke the resentment o the frontier settlers
backed by the power OF the stae. The Florida In
dams having recensiy committed murders and culra-
geo u"utfending citizens OF Georgia, SO say the
accounts, severe retaliation will in all probability,
be the consequence; and from the following resclu.
tons passed by the Legislature 0! Georgia, it is esi
dent that the indiscrcon OF the Indians will be
promptly punished We give it the mild term Of
indscretion because the conduct ofhe Indians is so
frequently misrepresened and exaggerated, and SO
frequently the resut OF bad advice received from the
whites, who urge them TO commit Offences hat they
may be driven further into the wilderness and their
possessions forfeited TO the cunning of their destroy
ers We seldom hear any thing Of the exciting
causes which urge The Indian TO war parte
statement, put forth by the successful TO suit their
oxun nd the NJ he
Indian, sufIces, and we look on with apathy at the
anhihilstion Of whole tribe driven TO desperation
by the ingenuity OF their oppressofs. Gazette.


RESOLUTIONS


PASSED BY THE LEGISLATURE OF GEORGIA.


Whereas his Exceency the Governor has re-
celsed and communicated TO this Legislature, in
formation that recent murders have been perpera-
ted upon certain citizens o this State on The Florida
line, by the Seminole Lower Creek Indians and
that murders have been repeated near the same
place upon individuals living on the Florida side Of
said line And further, that the Indians painted and
prepared for hostilies on the frontiers OF the State
having been taken by the United States force situa-
ted in that quarter, from whom information is re-
eeived that two hundred Indians embodied and
ready to make an invasion upon the settlers OF this
State and the danger oil such an invasion being SO ii
minent as to admit OF no delsy-


Resolved, That his Excellency the Governor take
immediate steps, by the Of the Militia or youn-
teer companies Of this State. TO lepe said invasion
as he may think proper either by arms or iortihca-
tions and in sufficient force to afford protection to
our frontiers and tha. the expense Of said expedi
ton be betrayed ou, Of the fund appropriated ior Mil
itary purposes.


/ Resolved, That, as il is provided by the 9th
ton of the first article Of the Federal Constitution
the General Government is bonnd to suppress in
surrec,ions and to repel invasons; and also o the
4th section of the 4th article Of said Constitution, Is
pledged to protect each state against invason--lhas
the Governor, without delay. call upon the Govern
